title: Getting started with Symptom Nerd
summary: A quick guide to logging and understanding patterns.

sections.heading: Log your first symptom
bullets: Tap Log Symptom from Home or Timeline.
Choose a symptom type and severity.
Add onset, duration, and any triggers.
Save and see it appear on your timeline.

sections.heading: Review your trends
bullets: Use Insights to view charts and averages.
Look for recurring triggers or time-of-day patterns.
Remember: these are observations, not diagnoses.

sections.heading: What to include
bullets: Onset: when it started and how quickly.
Severity: 0–10 scale over time.
Location: where it is on the body.
Quality: sharp, dull, throbbing, itchy, etc.

sections.heading: Context that can help
bullets: Sleep, hydration, caffeine, alcohol.
Stress level and screen time.
Meals, activity, and weather changes.

sections.heading: What AI can do
bullets: Summarize what you logged.
Highlight possible patterns or relationships.
Suggest questions to ask a clinician.

sections.heading: What AI cannot do
bullets: Provide a medical diagnosis.
Prescribe or change medications.
Replace professional medical care.

sections.heading: Before your appointment
bullets: Export the last 7–30 days for a focused view.
Include symptom frequency and severity trends.
Write down 1–3 key questions.

title: Preparing for a visit
summary: Turn your logs into a clear story.

sections.heading: Bring this with you
bullets: Symptom timeline and recent patterns.
Medication list and recent changes.
Questions you want answered.

title: Safety reminders
summary: Know when to seek urgent care.

sections.heading: Red flags
bullets: Sudden, severe symptoms or rapid worsening.
Chest pain, shortness of breath, fainting.
New neurological changes (confusion, weakness).
If you think this may be an emergency, call your local emergency number.
